awd_titl_txt: CHS: Small: Non-Programmer Authoring of Data-Driven Prediction Simulations
awd_abstract_narration:
This project explores ways to support educators as they introduce interactive data-driven activities to help learners develop intuitions about data and acquire specific analytic skills. While educators agree that the availability of data offers new educational opportunities in many disciplines, there is little consensus about how data-driven educational activities should be created. Often current solutions mandate teaching both instructors and students to program; these solutions are ambitious in scope, but can easily fall short of their aspirations, discouraging those who have difficulties learning to program and distracting the class from its primary educational goals. The prediction simulations framework enables an alternative type of activity, but how teachers perceive the opportunities and challenges offered by this type of activity, and how prediction simulations relate to their students, subject area, and educational context all pose new questions. Data analysis skills are a fundamental element of many disciplines, motivated by the widespread availability of datasets, ubiquitous sensing capabilities, and ready access to processing power. The ability to create prediction simulations has a potentially transformative effect on data science pedagogy. Concepts can be introduced to learners at different levels and disciplines to motivate learners and keep them engaged. Besides allowing learners to "dig into" data to develop their own understanding and construct better mental models of the underlying phenomena, prediction simulations can deepen a learner's understanding and intuition for the use of data in other domains. 

This project will provide an understanding of how teachers view the increasing availability of data in their domains, the tools and curricular activities currently available to them, and the overhead of creating and tailoring activities to their environment. Towards that goal, two interacting lines of research will be pursued: a multi-method study of the non-programmers who might create prediction simulations for use in pedagogical settings; and the design and evaluation of techniques to support authoring of prediction simulations. These two intertwined activities will help answer the following research questions: (1) What are the characteristics of domains, educators and students, and pedagogical situations that center on data analysis skills? Which would benefit from and be amenable to the introduction of prediction simulations? (2) Can generalized capabilities be developed to support the creation of novel situation-specific prediction simulations based on new combinations of datasets, visualizations, and analytic tools? (3) What are the most effective ways to support the authoring of new prediction simulations by non-programmers?  Methods to be investigated include template-based and specification-based authoring.

por.por_cntn:
This project explored support for the development of prediction games, activities designed to engage players in tasks that improve data analysis skills and domain knowledge. Prediction games ask players to make predictions related to real-world events. Predictions are scored when data about those events is available. The most popular example of prediction games is fantasy sports. Contributions of this project regarding the design of predication games are: the development of domain-independent software that can be used to create and run prediction games; and an analysis of how design alternatives affect player engagement and learning. In particular, the project explored the effects of supporting different modes of communication among players and of supporting different methods of access to domain-related news during gameplay.

Prediction games have value as part of a formal or informal educational setting when the games are tailored to specific domains and take account of the learners' existing knowledge levels. As such, educators who interact with learners have the best insight when selecting the game's domain and designing the particular predictions that learners are asked to make. A contribution of this project is the design and evaluation of a prediction game authoring environment to enable teachers or other curriculum developers to author prediction games without programming. An assessment of game developers with STEM backgrounds implementing a specified game and conceiving of new games on their own was performed. This evaluation showed that authoring unique prediction games without programming is possible within the limits of data available for use within the authoring environment. The evaluation exposed a trade-off inherent in computer support for game authoring. It found that, while many of the core activities of authoring could be supported without issue, having the authoring environment automatically generate certain game components resulted in authors having less understanding of how players would interact with the domain in question.  This was true even though we urged authors to edit aspects of the game that the system generated automatically.

Early in this project, we used crowdsourcing to gather data about participants' fantasy sports gameplay and engagement, so as to better understand which aspects of fantasy sports environments would be important in other domains. Later, when potential prediction game designers identified domains beyond those where existing data sources were available, crowdsourcing became interesting as a potential source of data for prediction games. This could take a similar form to some citizen science activities, where people upload observations or data from local environments and the larger data set generated is that used by a prediction game. Another opportunity is to build prediction activities around reactions to hypothetical events where the data about those reactions could be generated via crowdsourcing.  In such a scenario, the prediction game authoring tool could help develop the crowdsourcing tasks used to collect data as part of the authoring process.

Once we brought in crowdsourced data, data quality became an issue. As part of this project, the project examined data quality across domains to understand how privacy concerns, polarization, and engagement might effect data quality.  The results showed that current crowdsourced data quality is so bad that no distinctions could be made based on domain characteristics.  The project then examined crowdsourced data quality over time. Starting in about 2019, data quality issues became difficult to ignore. Although more than 97% of data collected from a task in 2013 would pass a multifaceted test for data quality, in 2022 only 11% of the data for the same task passes as acceptable. In short, while crowdsourcing could be a source for prediction games in the future, there is a data quality issue that is relatively recent that needs to be better understood and addressed.
